GLOSSARY 
 
value chain  –  A  value  chain  includes  the  full  range  of  activities  and  actors 
(enterprises) that are required to bring a product or service from its 
conception  to  the  final  consumer.  This  includes  input  supply, 
production  and  processing,  product  design,  distribution  and 
marketing, and support services. 
agribusiness  –  An individual enterprise engaged in commercial activity involving 
agricultural  products,  including  individual  farmers,  commercial 
farmer and herder groups, cooperatives, and enterprises involved 
in processing and trading of agricultural inputs and outputs.   
high mountain area  –  The  Ministry  of  Forestry  and  Soil  Conservation  classes  land 
systems of Nepal into five ecological zones: Terai, Siwaliks, middle 
mountain, high mountain, and high himal. High mountain districts 
generally range from 2,500 meters to 5,000 meters above sea 
level, although lower and higher altitude zones also occur in these 
districts.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to Nepal for the High Mountain Agribusiness and Livelihood Improvement (HIMALI) Project.1 
 
2.  The  project  will  assist  farmers  and  downstream  enterprises  to  strengthen  linkages, 
taking advantage of the gradual improvement in infrastructure, to realize the existing demand for 
mountain products. A demand-driven approach will be used to (i) mobilize interested producer 
groups; (ii) provide support for quality improvement, value adding, and product aggregation into 
quantities  of  scale  sufficient  to  attract  demand-side  business;  (iii) stimulate  private  sector 
agribusiness development; and (iv) reduce risk exposure to businesses investing in the high 
mountain districts. Project grants will be provided to eligible entities for implementing viable 
agribusiness plans that demonstrate income and employment benefits in the project districts. 
The  private  sector  has  expressed  interest  in  a  range  of  suitable  business  development, 
including (i) organized production of high-value products through contract or supply agreements; 
(ii) established collection, post-harvest quality grading, and storage facilities; (iii) processing and 
value adding; and (iv) quality certification to access high-value markets.2 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  About 80% of Nepal’s population lives in rural areas that have been left behind national 
economic growth. The high mountain areas are the least-developed among rural areas, mainly 
because  of  limited  access  to  markets  and  lack  of  investments.  These  areas  are  highly 
susceptible to the impact of climate change, for which Nepal is one of the most vulnerable 
countries in Asia. Nepal recently became a net food importer, partly because of lack of growth in 
agriculture, despite it employing 66% of the population and contributing about 35% to the 
country’s gross domestic product. The growth of the agriculture sector has been erratic largely 
because of its continued dependence on rainfall for irrigation and the dominance of cereal crop 
production—growth averaged only 2.5% in the past 5 years (FY2006–FY2010).3 Ten project 
districts4 were selected based on selection criteria including food insecurity5 (over 60% of the 
project district population is malnourished) and high incidence of poverty (over 60%).6 This is 
significantly greater than the country’s overall income poverty incidence rate of 31% and urban 
poverty  rate  of  10%. These  trends  also reflect  the  vulnerability  of  mountain  agriculture  to 
weather and geophysical conditions as well as infrastructural constraints.  
 
4.  The  widening  gap  between  rich  and  poor  regions  has  added  to  social  tensions, 
contributed to conflict in the past, and continued to pressure the government for solutions. 
Overgrazing and exploitation of forest and wild medicinal plants have degraded community 
livelihood assets and weakened resilience to climate change. Despite the significant contribution 
of agriculture to the economy, the sector’s performance is constrained by farmers’ limited

2    
access to services, marketing, and employment opportunities. More than 1 million Nepalese 
emigrate for employment abroad, resulting in seasonal households headed by women and 
feminization of agricultural labor. However, promising opportunities exist for the agriculture 
sector in value addition, marketing efficiency, reducing postharvest losses, and sustainable 
forest and rangeland production. 
 
5.  The project design is intended to contribute to the achievement of government and Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  development  outcomes,  reflecting  the  new  political  realities  and 
economic strategies of Nepal. Reflecting the lessons learned and recommendations in the 
Country Assistance Program Evaluation for the Country Strategy and Program 2005–2009,7 the 
ADB country partnership strategy 2010–2012 identifies the development outcomes as improved 
food security, rural livelihoods, employment opportunities, and agricultural income.8 A key to 
achieve these outcomes is commercialization of agricultural production. Mountain areas have 
no comparative advantage in cereals and low-value commodities, but have advantages in 
certain  traditional  and  high-value  products  including  wool,  certified  seeds,  off-season 
vegetables, dairy, meat, and medicinal and aromatic plant products (MAPs). These products 
have strong demand domestically and abroad, but commercial potential in mountain areas has 
been constrained by remoteness, fragmentation; and lack of infrastructure, farmers’ capital, and 
investment. In this context, the project is intended to strengthen agricultural production and 
linkages with markets, and improve the value addition retained by mountain people.  
 
6.  Off-farm  employment  provides  potential  for  investment  back  into  farming  and 
agribusiness.  With  improving  road,  communication,  and  access  to  financial  services, 
connectivity is growing between agribusiness and rural producers. Value chain studies and 
private sector consultations found increasing business interest in developing backward linkages 
to secure raw materials, and improve quality and cost efficiency by establishing facilities in 
mountain  districts  for  product  aggregation,  processing,  and  quality  management.9  A  rapid 
survey  resulted  in  130  expressions  of  interest  from  businesses  to  co-invest  in  mountain 
agribusiness development.10 There is potential to direct private sector investment and expertise 
into mountain areas, if assistance is provided to mobilize interested producer groups, link them 
to downstream agribusiness and markets, and assist them to develop and implement viable 
business plans. 
 
7.  Women increasingly make farming decisions, and invest labor in MAP collection and in 
cottage industry processing and weaving. Women often carry the burden of collecting firewood 
and livestock forage, and women’s community groups have shown interest in rehabilitation of 
community forest and rangelands for sustainable, reliable productivity. Women have successful 
enterprise groups for high-value products; e.g., carpets, sea buckthorn juice, traditional paper, 
and incense. These opportunities can be realized through social mobilization and provision of 
assistance to women and community groups to improve product quality and business skills, and 
to strengthen links with downstream business and markets. 
 
                                                
7  ADB. 2009. Country Assistance Program Evaluation for Nepal: Delivering Assistance in a Challenging 
Environment. Manila.  
8  ADB. 2010. Country Partnership Strategy: Nepal, 2010–2012. Manila. 
9  Agricultural value chain analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2), and recent studies by 
SNV  Netherlands  Development  Organization  and  the  International  Centre  for  Integrated  Mountain  Area 
Development (ICIMOD). 
10 Private Sector Interest (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

3 
8.  The  project  design  is  built  upon  the  lessons  learned,  institutional  structures,  and 
operational procedures established during the completed Crop Diversification Project (CDP)11 
and the Community Livestock Development Project (CLDP) for Nepal,12 and the Department for 
International Development of the United Kingdom-financed Livelihood from Forests Project. 
Research from the International Centre for Integrated Mountain Area Development in value 
chain development and community co-management of rangelands has also been integrated in 
the design. Lessons applied in the design of the project include (i) participatory and demand-
driven  targeting  of  development,  and  (ii)  contract  service  provision  and  community-based 
organizations to mitigate limited government capacity. 
 
9.  The  project  design  keeps  in  view  the  post-conflict  situation  and  weak  institutional 
capacities,  and  provides  flexibility  in  implementation  arrangements  to  allow  for  anticipated 
changes  in  governance  systems  and  structures.  Decentralized  and  participatory  project 
implementation, with strong involvement of nongovernment organization (NGO) community-
based groups and existing agribusiness structures, minimizes political risks.13 The Ministry of 
Agriculture  and  Cooperatives  (MOAC)  has  successful  experience  in  implementing 
commercialization projects through the Agro Enterprise Centre (AEC) of the Federation of Nepal 
Chambers of Commerce and Industry,14 and modalities to contract NGO services to improve 
outreach capacity in remote areas—developed and improved through projects including the 
CLDP, CDP, and Commercial Agriculture Development Project (CADP)15 in cooperation with 
ADB. These modalities have been refined and incorporated in the project design. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The project impact will be improved incomes in selected high mountain areas. The 
project outcome will be that mountain agribusinesses are commercially viable in selected high 
mountain districts. The project is expected to result in (i) an additional $20.0 million gross 
production  value  per  year;  (ii)  7,500  jobs  created  by  participating  enterprises;  and  (iii) 
participating business enterprises achieving a rate of return on investment of no less than 15% 
per annum by 2017. The project will also improve mountain communities’ resilience to climate 
change by supporting the implementation of elements of community climate change adaptation 
action plans,16 and community forestry and rangeland group action plans for timber, grazing, 
and medicinal plants collection.17  
 
C.  Outputs 
11.  Three main outputs are envisaged: (i) an increased number of mountain agribusinesses 
making use of agribusiness grants, (ii) mountain agribusinesses have knowledge and access to

Kingdom of Nepal for the Community Livestock Development Project. Manila.

farmers even with an adverse security situation, through sound social mobilization and grassroots support.

4    
improved production technologies and value-addition,18 and (iii) effective project management at 
central and district levels.  The project will help agribusinesses, including individual farmers and 
farmer groups, which meet eligibility criteria, apply for small and medium-sized agribusiness 
grants provided by the project. Applicants must contribute a minimum of 20% to the cost of any 
agribusiness proposal. Applicants must be (i) legally registered19  farmer groups, cooperatives, 
or  community  organizations  with  business  based  on  mountain  agricultural  products;20  (ii) 
registered community forestry groups and rangeland grazing groups; (iii) agribusiness firms 
registered under the Nepal Company Act, with formal contract or direct supply links with value 
chain participants in high mountains; or (iv) individual business persons (legally registered with 
a tax number) with at least five employees in the business and located in the HIMALI mountain 
districts. Staff of MOAC, the HIMALI project and its contracted service providers, and their 
family  members  are  not  eligible.  Agribusiness  grant  applications  will  be  assessed  by  an 
independent grant assessment committee, in line with assessment criteria specified in the 
project administration manual (PAM).21 The agribusiness grants will assist agribusinesses to 
implement their business plans, thereby strengthening commercial activity and building links in 
value chain corridors, from input suppliers and producers to downstream marketing and agro-
processing businesses.   
 
12.  The following are examples of the business activities and facilities that will be considered 
for HIMALI agribusiness grants: (i) production, processing, value-adding, and manufacture of 
finished mountain products; (ii) collection, storage, grading, quality management, packing for 
distribution,  and  marketing;  (iii)  agro-tourism  including  locally  produced  food  services, 
handicrafts, and agricultural and natural resource experience-based tourism services products; 
(iv) facilities for aggregating and exporting agro-products from HIMALI mountain districts,  and 
draft animal services and way-station facilities; (v) tracks, culverts and short road connections 
that are essential for agribusiness development and that are co-funded by the concerned farmer 
groups or agribusiness (i.e., not public tracks and roads); (vi) small-scale irrigation and water 
harvesting works that are owned, managed, and maintained by registered farmer groups; and 
(vii) nurseries, planting, and small civil works for community forestry and rangeland business 
resource development, including for timber, grazing and MAPs.  
 
13.  To  improve  sustainability,  the  project  will  provide  agribusinesses  with  training  in 
improved production and agro-processing technical and business knowledge. On a demand- 
driven basis, agribusinesses will receive assistance from the AEC, and to a lesser extent from 
NGOs, in the preparation of business plans. The project will also upgrade five agricultural 
research and development stations to provide support and services to the private sector. 
 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans 
 
14.  The  investment  project  will  comprise  three  components:  (i)  mountain  agribusiness 
development, (ii) value chain capacity development, and (iii) project management. Investment 
and financing plans are in Tables 1 and 2.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  MOAC  will  be  the  executing  agency  and  will  carry  out  implementation  through  the 
Department of Livestock Services (DLS) and be responsible for overall project management and 
coordination. AEC will be an implementing agency and responsible for implementation of part of 
component 1. ADB will execute a separate project agreement with AEC for this purpose. MOAC 
will establish a steering committee and a central PMU located in the DLS. MOAC will appoint to 
the PMU a full-time project director (class I officer), a finance officer, and administration officer 
to ensure compliance with government regulations. The PMU will contract additional support 
staff (accounting, administration, monitoring, reporting, and others) locally. The DLS regional 
directorates and senior DLS or DOA officers in each project district will assist in coordination, 
monitoring, and evaluation as part of their line responsibilities.

6    
18.  To  mitigate  capacity  constraints  when  implementing  projects  in  remote  areas, 
experience from other projects suggests that consultants attached to the PMU, and service 
providers at the field level, are essential for timely and successful implementation. Therefore, 
the PMU will be supported by (i) an independent agribusiness grant assessment committee 
(GAC) comprising experts contracted on a piece rate (i.e., per grant application assessed); and 
(ii) international consultants (49 person-months, for start-up and capacity building) and national 
consultants  (446  person-months  for  the  PMU  and  needs-based  technical  advice).  The 
consultants  will  be  recruited  through  the  quality-based  selection  procedures  for  the  PMU 
consultants and NGO management contract (package one), and the agribusiness capacity 
development contract (package two). Beneficiary communication and mobilization of farmer 
groups will be conducted by NGOs recruited by the firm providing the PMU consultants. AEC 
will  implement  activities  to  mobilize  agribusiness,  including  farmers  and  farmer  groups,  to 
provide  business  planning  and  market  linkage  services  to  beneficiaries,  and  assist  with 
preparing grant applications and implementation of business development plans.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Economic and Financial 
20.  The project will address livelihoods in high mountain areas through development of 
relevant  value  chains,  promoting  productive  private  sector  investments,  and  public  sector 
infrastructure and services. Quantifiable economic benefits are expected only from the mountain 
agribusiness development component. Agribusiness development is strongly viable, with an 
economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for the investments of 27.2% and of 23.8% including the 
component promotion and implementation costs. For the whole project, this benefits stream 
produces a robust EIRR of 16.7%. The EIRR is not sensitive to a 10% increase in costs nor to a 
10% reduction in benefit, but falls slightly to 15.3% if benefits are delayed for 1 year. This 
sensitivity will be mitigated by the agribusiness capacity development consultant inputs in the 
first 18 months, as well as sufficient provision for delivery of support services to beneficiaries by 
AEC and social mobilization. 
 
21.  Based on cash flow analyses of 22 possible investments, the investment grants of 
$18.7 million will generate annual revenues of $17.6 million. Shared between profits, wages, 
agricultural supplies, and other supplies and services, members of the mountain communities 
are projected to receive $10.6 million of these annual income streams. 
 
B.  Governance 
22.  To ensure consistency, transparency, and economy in the procurement of goods, works, 
and services, the PMU will adhere to the Government of Nepal’s Public Procurement Act and 
Public Procurement Regulations 2007, and ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended 
from time to time) and Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time).  To  improve  accuracy  in  accounting  and  reduce  the  governance  risk,  the  PMU  will 
establish  a  double  entry  accounting system.  Proprietary  accounting  software, training, and 
system establishment will be provided under the project. In addition, the PMU will prepare and 
implement a robust code of conduct for their staff involved in the project—ensuring, that the staff 
members working at the PMU do not have any conflict of interest with any sub-grant applicants. 
The government will take the necessary steps to ensure that all applicable anticorruption laws of 
Nepal, which apply to public officials, are effectively enforced.  
 
23.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  Government  of  Nepal  and  its  executing  agency,  MOAC.  The  specific  policy 
requirements  and  supplementary  measures  are  described  in  the  PAM.  Supplementary 
governance measures include the use of an independent grant assessment committee for grant 
assessment  determination,  agribusiness  grant  payments  by  installment  to  allow  progress 
inspections to ensure funds are being used for the intended purpose of use, and direct payment 
to suppliers for procurement of equipment and contractors. 
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
24.  The project will generate employment for 7,500 men and women, directly benefitting up 
to 5,000 households in the project area. In the longer term, it will contribute to improving the 
lives of at least 88,00022 households active in various value chains through improved access to 
                                                
22 Some 60% of households in the project districts are producers in at least one of the main agricultural value chains. 
More are involved in processing, trade, transport, and other forms of economic engagement, both within and 
outside the project area. See Poverty and Social Assessment (accessible from the list of linked documents in 
Appendix 2).

8    
markets, services, and employment. Poor and socially excluded groups will gain opportunities 
for employment and supply of raw materials such as wool and MAPs, which do not necessarily 
require cash investment or ownership of land. Increased economic activity will also contribute to 
reinvigorating local societies and improving livelihood rewards to women in agriculture, herders, 
and traditional niche product producers. Such benefits will be realized through implementation 
of the gender and equity social inclusion (GESI) plan. 
 
D.  Safeguards 
25.  Environment. The project is categorized B regarding potential environmental impacts. 
An initial environmental examination was conducted on project activities, including assessment 
of 22 representative agribusiness models, and rehabilitation of representative MOAC district 
offices and research stations. The initial environmental examination indicates minor potential 
impacts during rehabilitation and construction of facilities (quarrying and timber use must be 
sustainable) and from agribusiness operations (e.g., sustainable sourcing of raw materials and 
firewood, and appropriate waste management). Positive impacts are expected from improved 
incomes resulting in less reliance on wild resources, and from support to implement community 
forestry,  rangeland  management,  and  climate  adaptation  action  plans.  An  environmental 
assessment and review framework has been prepared, and subprojects that may have an 
impact on protected areas of ecological or archaeological values will be screened out during the 
subproject identification phase. 
 
26.  Resettlement.  The  project  is  categorized  C  regarding  involuntary  resettlement.  No 
negative  resettlement  or  social  impacts  are  expected.  The  project  will  not  involve  land 
acquisition. The project will support screened agribusiness proposals that include productive 
infrastructure, and will upgrade MOAC facilities on government land. Resettlement due diligence 
is part of the proposal selection criteria. All agribusiness proposals must include evidence of 
land ownership or land rights-of-way. Any issue of resettlement will result in the GAC rejecting 
the  proposal.  Due  diligence  to  obtain  evidence  of  land  ownership  will  be  carried  out  by 
agribusiness proponents.  
 
27.  Indigenous  people. The  project  is categorized  B  regarding  impacts  on  indigenous 
people. During project preparation, extensive and meaningful consultation was undertaken with 
indigenous peoples in the project districts consistent with five requirements specified in the 
Safeguards Policy Statement (2009, as amended to date). The project has only positive benefits 
to  indigenous  people.  For  disadvantaged  indigenous  peoples,  barriers  to  participation  and 
benefit by indigenous people are similar to those of other disadvantaged groups, and have been 
addressed through project activities listed in the poverty reduction and social strategy, and the 
GESI plan. A separate indigenous people plan has not been prepared because the indigenous 
peoples constitute about half of the project beneficiaries and the project has only positive 
impacts  on  them.  As  permitted  by  the  Safeguards  Policy  Statement,  the  elements  of  an 
indigenous  people  plan  have  been  integrated  with  the  report  and  recommendation  of  the 
President. 
 
28.  Some indigenous people are trade and business leaders in their areas and will be 
important actors in agribusiness development. Other marginalized groups may face participation 
constraints. The project recognizes that successful business development will not be driven by 
marginalized indigenous people with low skills and financial risk taking ability, but they will 
benefit directly from employment in expanded commercial activity and better value marketing 
opportunities. Due diligence required to meet selection criteria for project agribusiness grants, 
and a comprehensive communication strategy, provide sufficient safeguards to avoid negative 
impacts and to enhance positive impacts for indigenous people. The concerns of indigenous

9 
people are no different from those of other categories of disadvantaged groups (e.g., Dalits, 
landless people, or women) and are covered in a GESI plan. The project will be implemented in 
compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. 
 
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
29.  The project is categorized low risk. The Asian Development Fund project is built on the 
successful experience of the ADB-financed CDP, and the CLDP, which was rated successful in 
its project completion report.23 The fluid political situation and potential for conflict affected the 
achievements of these projects, and remains the main risk. The executing agency, MOAC, has 
capacity  and  experience  in  implementing  externally  financed  projects,  and  safeguard 
categorization is B or C. 
 
30.  Stringent financial management assessment by the PMU will mitigate financial risks 
associated  with  business  development  by  farmer  groups  and  agro-enterprises.  Financial 
governance is a serious concern in Nepal. For agribusiness grant disbursements, risk mitigation 
is through the use of agribusiness grant agreements (legal contracts), and vendor payment and 
post-payment for final grant installment following verification of investments by field staff.  
 
31.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4.

IV.  ASSURANCES 
32.  The government and MOAC have assured ADB that implementation of the project will 
conform  to  ADB’s  policies  on  anticorruption,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting 
services, and disbursement as described in detail in the PAM and grant agreement.  
 
33.  The government and MOAC have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, 
which are set forth in the grant agreement and project agreement.  
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
34.  I am satisfied that the proposed grant would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  grant  not 
exceeding $20,000,000 to Nepal, from ADB’s Special Funds resources, for the High Mountain 
Agribusiness  and  Livelihood  Improvement  Project,  on  terms  and  conditions  that  are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft grant and project agreements 
presented to the Board.
